Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Post-Operative Radiotherapy in Resected NSCLC

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either PORT using modern techniques or no PORT.

Participants.evidence: This multicenter randomised controlled trial included patients with resected NSCLC.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either PORT using modern techniques or no PORT.

Objective.evidence: This trial assesses the impact of PORT on disease-free survival (DFS) and overall survival (OS).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was DFS over a 5-year period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to patients or clinicians, but outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 501 patients were randomised, with 250 in the PORT group and 251 in the control group, recruited between 2010 and 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the intention-to-treat analysis, PORT significantly reduced mediastinal recurrence.

Result_Outcome.evidence: PORT significantly reduced mediastinal recurrence (HR 0.71, 95% CI: 0.51–0.97) but did not improve DFS or OS (HR 1.02, 95% CI: 0.68–1.52).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were more frequent in the PORT group, with grade 3 or 4 cardiopulmonary toxicities in 11% compared to 5% in the control group.
